p: Antimalarial plants used in Kenya are majorly shrubs (33.2%), trees (30.1%), and herbs (29.7%) ( Figure 2), and the commonly used plant parts are leaves (27.7%) and roots (19.4%) followed by bark (10.8%), root bark (10.5%), and stem bark (6.9%) ( Figure 3). Comparatively, plant parts such as fruits, seeds, buds, bulbs, and flowers which have reputation for accumulating phytochemicals are rarely used, similar to reports from other countries [ 26, 28, 33].
